none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. H. Dinwiddie, July 30, 1883
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. H. Dinwiddie, July 30, 1883
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 14 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
College Station July 30 - 1883

My dear McInnis -

Your letter was brought by
todays mail and heartily welcomed. It finds
us like Mark Tapley in "Eden", only sustained
by what each has of the Talent "for coming out
strong under difficulties". Mark would be up=
roariously cheerful here now. Fannie is in bed
with the fashionable "remittent", Bessie looking
sad and wan is crawling feebly about from
one ward to another of our hospital. I am at
my old combined occupations of nurse, cook,
housekeeper, general messenger and man of all
work. Bringhurst is very helpful and kind.
You may congratulate yourself on being anywhere
but here at this time. However Mrs. D. is better
this morning and I hope to get all hands up to
the traveling point in a few days and then
away they go to higher lands. If I can keep on
my feet a week longer you may expect me to be
on hand at the Lindell when you step from the
'bus on the 9th.
Girardeau gave you a splendid send off in the
issue following your visit. I have the article
and will try in town to get some extra copies.

**Analysis and Transcription of a Handwritten Letter** Alright, let's break this down. First, I need to understand what I'm looking at. It's a handwritten letter on either lined or plain paper – might be faint lines there. The date and location are at the top right: "College Station July 30 - 1883". The salutation is "My dear McInnis -". Now for the body. The letter mentions someone's letter being welcomed, and that the writer is in a difficult situation, like "Mark Tapley in 'Eden'," making reference to Dickens. There's talk of someone named Fannie being sick with "remittent fever" (likely malaria), and another person, Bessie, is also ill, and the writer is doing everything from nursing to housework. There is help from someone named Bringhurst. The writer suggests McInnis is lucky to be elsewhere, but things will improve soon. The writer hopes to meet McInnis at the Lindell on the 9th, and mentions a good send-off from Girardeau, which may be a person or a newspaper, after a visit. I need to get copies of the article. I'll start with the header, right-aligned: `College Station July 30 - 1883`. Then the salutation: `My dear McInnis -`. Now the body. I'll transcribe each line carefully, paying close attention to punctuation and formatting as per the instructions, particularly making sure to use line breaks as needed to replicate the layout. I'll look closely at words like "todays," "Talent," the hyphens in lines, and names like "Bringhurst," "Lindell," and "Girardeau". It appears "Mrs. D." is written and there is no reason to think it is "Dr." or "Mrs. P." The letter indicates 'D'. The draft HTML will look like this, preserving line breaks. ```html

College Station July 30 - 1883

My dear McInnis -

Your letter was brought by
todays mail and heartily welcomed. It finds
us like Mark Tapley in "Eden", only sustained
by what each has of the Talent "for coming out
strong under difficulties". Mark would be up=
roariously cheerful here now. Fannie is in bed
with the fashionable "remittent", Bessie looking
sad and wan is crawling feebly about from
one ward to another of our hospital. I am at
my old combined occupations of nurse, cook,
housekeeper, general messenger and man of all
work. Bringhurst is very helpful and kind.
You may congratulate yourself on being anywhere
but here at this time. However Mrs. D. is better
this morning and I hope to get all hands up to
the traveling point in a few days and then
away they go to higher lands. If I can keep on
my feet a week longer you may expect me to be
on hand at the Lindell when you step from the
'bus on the 9th.
Girardeau gave you a splendid send off in the
issue following your visit. I have the article
and will try in town to get some extra copies.

``` I will check the formatting, paying special attention to capitalization and punctuation. The spelling looks good for words like "remittent," "Lindell", "Bringhurst", and "Girardeau" and for names like "Fannie", and "Bessie". Line breaks must preserve the visual format of the letter. This looks correct. The HTML formatting should be exactly as the code is drafted above. And I think that should be it.

[1883, July 30]

I think you got the kinks out of the Post. I
am anxious to hear how they got into it. This
we may discuss over the foaming tankard at Mr.
Anheuser's very headquarters.

All is quiet here so far as business is concerned.
Gen. Hardeman takes hold quietly but energeti=
cally. He has had workmen inspecting the prem=
ises and promises to put the ball in motion
in a few days. Nothing definite from Austin
yet. Applications for Catalogues coming in.

We have a catalogue to be proud of this time (?)
Nile green cover – kiss-me-quick-and-treat-me-to-
strawberry-ice-cream tinted "innards". It is
too-too-too, and the rosy hues of the paper were
eminently fitted to prepare the mind of the
reader for the rhetoric inside, which however
the ruthless hand of the vandal chemist struck
with partial oblivion. It may pass, but is still
something of a mess. May it be the last relic
of the most fearful blunder in our history!

You will not expect a longer letter than this
now. I will bring your letters. The kitchen and
the hospital call for me. The ladies appreciate
your kind remembrance and send regards.

Even Norrell looks depressed today and puts

**Transcribing a Handwritten Letter** Okay, here's what I'm thinking. First, I need to understand what's being asked of me. It's transcription, so I'm aiming for accuracy above all else, but I also need to preserve the layout, which means line breaks and any paragraph structure are crucial. I should also keep an eye out for any formatting elements, like tables, as mentioned in the instructions. So, here's how I'll approach this image: I'll start from the top and work my way down, line by line, really looking at each word. I'm going to carefully read each paragraph, making sure I transcribe it correctly, and keeping the line breaks. First thing, there's a date in the top right: `[1883, July 30]`. Then I have the first paragraph. I see "Post" in the first line. Then, there's "Anheuser's". It must be a reference to the brewery. Next paragraph: Seems to be about business and a General Hardeman. I see those hyphens at the end of some lines. I'll keep those. The third paragraph talks about a catalogue. There's a curious color description – "Nile green cover - kiss-me-quick-and-treat-me-to- strawberry-ice-cream tinted 'innards'". I’ll have to transcribe that exactly as written, even if it's a bit odd. I’m guessing it is a quote, so I will note that. The "vandal chemist" phrase is odd as well. I think the reference is to the printing process, given the context. The fourth paragraph is pretty straightforward, the writer is wrapping things up, mentions a kitchen and a hospital. In the last line, I see a name. Looks like "Norrell" or possibly "Harrell". Going with "Norrell", as it’s consistent with a clear ‘N’. his hand on his stomach and shakes his head
sadly at the mention of ice and things.
Auf Wiedersehen!

Faithfully Yours -
[Signature]
[H.H. Dinwiddie]
